content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Many people who suffer from a common skin ailment decide to buy a generic brand skin cream instead of a name-brand skin cream because of cost savings. A skin doctor plans to investigate the following claim made in an advertisement. The generic brand of a skin cream is less effective in curing a common skin ailment than a name-brand skin cream. The doctor is considering the following two options for the design of a study: Option A: Obtain <math alttext="500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with the skin ailment who use the generic brand skin cream each day. Obtain <math alttext="500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with the skin ailment who use the name-brand skin cream each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after six months. Option B: Randomly assign <math alttext="1,000" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,000</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers with the skin ailment to one of two groups, each with <math alttext="500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people. Give the name-brand skin cream to one group to be used each day and the generic brand skin cream to the other group to be used each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after six months. (a) Give a reason why Option B is more appropriate than Option A for investigating the effectiveness of the skin cream. Justify your answer in the context of the problem.

An appropriate hypothesis test will be conducted to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence to support the claim about skin cream made in the advertisement.(d) State, in words, the hypotheses for the appropriate test.

Assume all conditions for the test of the hypotheses from part (d) are met.
